Article.Abstract: The sequence 260-283 of the nucleoprotein (NP) of influenza A virus is an epitope recognized by virus-immune lymph node cells from CBA (H-2k), B6 (H-2b), and B10.S (H-2s) mice. Further analysis shows that there are at least two Th epitopes within this sequence: the one close to the N-terminal (p260-273) is recognized by T cells from CBA and B6 mice while that close to the carboxyl-terminal (p270-283) is a dominant Th determinant in B10.S mice. The fine specificity of the recognition of this epitope by NP-specific T cell clones is also studied. When B10.S mice were infected intranasally or i.v. with live influenza virus, or immunized by different ways with various Ag preparations, P270-283 persistently emerged as a dominant T cell epitope. Immunization of B10.S mice with peptide p270-283 induces T cells with different in vivo functions including class II-restricted cytotoxicity, cognate help for Ag-specific antibody synthesis and delayed type hypersensitivity. This may have important implications for the understanding of the differentiation and classification of subsets of CD4+ T cells. The corresponding sequence of the NP of an equine influenza virus, A/Eq/Prague/56, which has a substitution (leucine to proline) at position 283, was not recognized by the lymph node cells from mice primed with either A/Okuda or A/Eq/Prague. However, the peptide, p270-283(E), representing this sequence induced T cell responses to both human and equine viruses. The data are discussed with respect to the development of viral vaccines.
Article.ArticleTitle: A dominant Th epitope in influenza nucleoprotein. Analysis of the fine specificity and functional repertoire of T cells recognizing a single determinant.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Viral;Epitopes;Interleukin-3;NP protein, Influenza A virus;Nucleoproteins;Oligopeptides;RNA-Binding Proteins;Viral Core Proteins;Viral Proteins;Proline

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.
Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.
Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.
Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.

Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse. Similar conditions were used for immunization with source protein, with similar results. 7 days after immunization with source species, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro with source species (PR8 strain) for 5 days before assaying their cytotoxic activity.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells shown previously to proliferate in response to peptide in a CD4+/MHC-II restricted fashion are able to lyse peptide pulsed cells after short term culture with source species (PR8 strain).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail in a 100 microliter volume per mouse. 7 days after immunization with attenuated S. typhimurium expressing recombinant source protein from Influenza, lymph node cells were cloned and restimulated weekly with source species (PR8 strain) and syngeneic irradiated splenocytes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: 2 T cell clones raised from source protein immunized mice with in vitro restimulation with source species (PR8 strain) proliferate in response to epitope and to a truncated version of it. One of the clones respond to 273-283 as the minimal epitope, while the other responds to 275-283 as the minimal epitope, proving that a heterogeneous Th population responds to this immunodominant epitope. Since the epitope contains 2 Cys residues, a S-S bond could be responsible for the specificity of the recognition, but mutation of one of those residues does not affect recognition, implying the bond is either not formed or not important for recognition. The P283 residue mutation to Leucine abolishes its recognition by T cell clones, implying it is a critical residue. This mutation is found naturally in the equine A/Eq/Prague strain of Influenza.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells proliferate in response to peptide when derived from source species immunized B10.S mice. In CBA and B6 mice, on the contrary, this peptide is not stimulatory, while peptide 260-273 is.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 1 mg/ml solution of peptide emulsified in CFA in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells proliferate in response to Flu A/PR8/34 (epitope is conserved), source species and source protein when derived from peptide immunized B10.S mice. In CBA and B6 mice, on the contrary, this peptide is not immunogenic nor stimulatory, while peptide 260-273 is. In B10.S, this peptide is shown to induce a T helper response that includes delayed-type hypersensitivity and peptide specific immunoglobulin synthesis enhancement.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.
Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 1 mg/ml solution of peptide emulsified in CFA in a 100 microliter volume per mouse. Also B6 mice were studied with similar results.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells proliferate in response to Flu A/PR8/34 (epitope is conserved) and peptide when derived from peptide immunized CBA mice and also B6 mice. In B10.S mice, on the contrary, this peptide is not immunogenic nor stimulatory, while peptide 270-283 is.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 1 mg/ml solution of peptide emulsified in CFA in a 100 microliter volume per mouse. Also B6 mice were studied with similar results.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: In B10.S mice this peptide is not immunogenic nor stimulatory, while peptide 270-283 is. The opposite situation is observed in B6 and CBA mice.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells from B10.S mice do not proliferate in response to this peptide when derived from source species- or peptide-immunized mice. In CBA and B6 mice, on the contrary, this peptide is highly immunogenic and stimulatory.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Immunization was performed in the base of the tail with 50 micrograms saponin as adjuvant, in a 100 microliter volume per mouse. Also B6 mice were studied with similar results.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Lymph node cells proliferate in response to peptide when derived from source species immunized CBA and B6 mice. In B10.S mice, on the contrary, this peptide is not stimulatory, while peptide 270-283 is.
